block.p: Sharon Vows to Raise West Bank Security Wall Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel rebuffed pressure from President Bush to halt construction of a security wall on the West Bank and called on Mr. Bush to convince Palestinian leaders to do more to dismantle terrorist groups.

The Palestinian Authority's security minister said his forces in the West Bank had prevented seven terror attacks against Israel in the past month, but did not make any arrests because Israel still controls those areas. Each side continues to accuse the other of failing to meet its obligations under the peace initiative.

A Quickening Hunt for Hussein American military officials said they were confident they had picked up the trail of Saddam Hussein as soldiers made dozens of raids and seized more than 175 suspected Hussein loyalists. An Arabic-language television station broadcast an audiotape it said carried the voice of Mr. Hussein calling for revenge as he mourned the death of his sons.

Senators from both parties assailed President Bush's budget director and deputy defense secretary for refusing to detail how much the postwar effort will cost and how many American troops will be needed.
The Bush administrations nominee for Army chief of staff, Gen. Peter J. Schoomaker, said the Army probably needs more troops to meet its worldwide commitments.

Liberia Rejects Cease-Fire Liberia rejected a rebel offer of a truce as shells slammed into Monrovia suburbs despite the insurgents' pledge to stop fighting and let West African peacekeepers occupy the capital. Weary residents doubt any cease-fire will work.

Mobs Rally in Guatemala Well-organized mobs in Guatemala City rallied in support of Efraín Ríos Montt, the former general and dictator who is seeking the presidency even as a debate rages in the courts about his right to do so.

Bush Refuses to Release Secret Part of 9/11 Report President Bush refused to declassify a 28-page chapter of a Congressional report on the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, that centers on accusations of Saudi Arabia's role in financing the hijackings.

Rise of a Contender Howard Dean, the former Vermont governor, has burst from his obscurity as an antiwar gadfly in a crowded field of Democrats to rank among the top contenders for the party's presidential nomination.

Mistrial in Brutality Case A mistrial was declared in the case of a California police officer who was videotaped last year slamming a 16-year-old boy onto a patrol car. The jury said that it was deadlocked.

Drug Lobby Pushed Letter A trade group helped coordinate a signature campaign in the Senate opposing legislation allowing Americans to import less expensive medicines and hailed the signed letter as proof of its argument that the bill would jeopardize patient safety.

Alternatives for Head Start Senate Democrats and a Republican are offering separate proposals for revising the federal Head Start program, neither of which adopts the most controversial change in the version the House passed last week: permitting eight states to take over the program.
A Budget for California The California Assembly approved by a 56-to-22 vote a nearly $100 billion state budget that cuts deeply into education and health care spending but does not raise taxes.
Professors Comment on Risk Economists, psychologists and statisticians say that managers, coaches and players are often too cautious for their own good.

City May Be Emerging From Fiscal Crisis There is evidence that New York City is emerging from its fiscal crisis for the first time since the terrorist attacks of 2001, a startling turnaround that is a result of a budget formula consisting of higher taxes, service cuts, extra aid and greater government efficiency.
Pataki Holds Back Funds Governor Pataki is refusing to sign off on millions of dollars that legislators can dole out for projects in their backyards.

Polio Virus Security The World Health Organization is encouraging laboratories with stocks of the polio virus to either take measures to prevent accidental release, or destroy them. Dr. Jong Wook Lee, the W.H.O.'s new director, declared they will need $210 million in order to eradicate the virus by 2005.
Ozone Layer Destruction Slows Scientists monitoring the highest levels of the atmosphere say they have detected a slowing in the rate of destruction of the earth's protective veil of ozone.
Columbia Plans to Expand Columbia University, long starved for land, is buying up a 17-acre swath in West Harlem for its first major expansion in 75 years.
Hoping to Head Off a Strike Verizon and its labor unions met with a federal mediator in an effort to avoid a walkout that could affect phone service in 13 New England and Middle Atlantic States.
Executive Leaves Merrill Thomas H. Patrick Sr., the vice chairman of Merrill Lynch, retired abruptly, surprising Wall Street.
MGM Pulls Offer to Vivendi Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer withdrew its $11.5 billion offer for Vivendi Universal's entertainment businesses.
Rough Road for MCI Accusations that MCI used fraudulent schemes to cut charges could make it harder for the company to keep customers and find new ones.
